caption:
- Dropped off, picked up, dropped off.
- Paid a toll.
- Set up a chat with someone about Lexington, then later realized Lexington is probably too expensive. Still, information about schools outside Cambridge may just help in general with knowing where we can go.
- Parent tech support.
- Did laundry — including folding!
- Client B work.
- Concluded trying out Pixi. While I'm sure its implemenation is far better than the one in my own "engine", it doesn't really provide that much more, as far I can tell. I was hoping for hit detection, which seems very hairy to me, but that's beyond its scope, and I'd have to bring along my own crappy hit detection. Still might use it. I tried Phaser for a bit, but it creates a bundle that's 7 MB minimum. The build takes over a minute with just example code.
- Looked at some BC school stats. It was hard to get a sense for things outside of Vancouver (much of which is going to be underwater).
htmlFragment:

caption:
A brief report on me and Ruby on Rails interest

2007: Everyone's doing it. I do a tutorial, then forget about it.

2018: I want to work for Bandcamp, who seems to only hire Rails devs. I think about learning it, then don't actually try.

2022: Bandcamp is bought by Fortnite; I am vindicated.
htmlFragment:
• 3/4/2022, 4:49:27 PM
    A brief report on me and Ruby on Rails interest

    2007: Everyone's doing it. I do a tutorial, then forget about it.

    2018: I want to work for Bandcamp, who seems to only hire Rails devs. I think about learning it, then don't actually try.

    2022: Bandcamp is bought by Fortnite; I am vindicated.

caption:
I think I finished one of the songs for the EP I've been planning since the summer. Back then, I thought, four songs, easy!

The current state of the songs:

1. Almost done, or so I think. Just one more layer needs to be written.
2. There is a demo.
3. There is a really rough demo.
4. Done. (But there's always a chance I listen to it next week and think, no, this is garbage.)

caption:
TypeScript is good for some things. If you like named arguments in functions (functions that take objects), it gets rough, though. Here is what it looks like when you make one of those, and you want default values.

    export function getNByNGraph(
      { points, startProp, destProp, distProp }:
      { points: IdPt[]; startProp: string; destProp: string; distProp: string } = 
      { points: [], startProp: 'from', destProp: 'to', distProp: 'weight' }
    ): IdPt[] {

It's like a little essay preamble of its own.
htmlFragment:
• 3/8/2022, 4:32:59 PM
    TypeScript is good for some things. If you like named arguments in functions (functions that take objects), it gets rough, though. Here is what it looks like when you make one of those, and you want default values.

        export function getNByNGraph(
          { points, startProp, destProp, distProp }:
          { points: IdPt[]; startProp: string; destProp: string; distProp: string } = 
          { points: [], startProp: 'from', destProp: 'to', distProp: 'weight' }
        ): IdPt[] {

    It's like a little essay preamble of its own.

caption: I forget the question marks in that last post, but the idea of fixing that is exhausting.
htmlFragment:
• 3/8/2022, 4:35:43 PM
    I forget the question marks in that last post, but the idea of fixing that is exhausting.

caption:
Ah, that last snippet I posted provided a default argument for the entire object. Here's what you need for defaults for values in that object:

export function getNByNGraph(
  { points, startProp = 'from', destProp = 'to', distProp = 'weight' } :
  { points: IdPt[]; startProp?: string; destProp?: string; distProp?: string } 
): IdPt[] {

Woe to thee if you try to intuit syntax here.
htmlFragment:
• 3/8/2022, 4:55:55 PM

    export function getNByNGraph(
      { points, startProp = 'from', destProp = 'to', distProp = 'weight' } :
      { points: IdPt[]; startProp?: string; destProp?: string; distProp?: string } 
    ): IdPt[] {

caption:
- Dropped off, picked up, dropped off.
- Dealt with a condo finance thing which only took five minutes, but still felt stressful, as it always does.
- Booked a location scouting trip.
- Looked at a few map generation algorithms. I didn't like any of them, so I'm rastering lines and circles; which I think is a variant of something I did a decade ago, but since I can't find that code, I'll never know. It's sort of working? I have at least one bug.
- Sent a question to an eye doctor.
- Made dinner.
- Emailed a friend back.

caption:
Northampton has few death metal bands, but plenty of stoner doom.

Cambridge has two total metal bands on Metallum.

Somerville also has two.

Malden had one.

Medford has four.

Arlington has two.

Nothing for Stow.

Whoa, five in Amherst, including Lich King.

One in South Hadley!

Two in Acton.

Holy shit, why are there 63 metal bands in Worcester?

Lowell has 23. Graveheart is fun. They also have an accomplished video game cover band. (Warning: NSFW/embarrassing-to-be-seen-looking-at album cover.)

Fall River has seven. There may be some correlation to economic depression.

Brockton has ten, and they've been around a while.

Everett has two.

So, maybe the correlation isn't that tight.

Swinging back the other way to rich towns, Weston has none, nor do Dover, Sherborn

Brookline has one, and Newton has two, Lexington has one, Belmont has two, and Watertown has three.

Keep in mind that not every metal band is on Metallum, but it's quite compehensive, and small bands are motivated to get themselves on there, so I don't think this is out-of-touch with reality. I might do a more formal analysis later.
